The good:
- You can fly a spaceship to different planets, build stuff on them, harvest resources, and discover neat stuff.
- Lots of cool ideas that are implemented reasonably well (minus all the cut beta content)
- It's like Terraria, but with more sci-fi stuff. If that's your bag, it's a decent solo experience.

The bad:
- Dated design that was "abandoned" (finished development) nearly a decade ago. Multiplayer is not stable enough for me.
- Runs on one CPU core for both clients and dedicated servers, meaning performance can be a mixed bag. Doesn't engage the GPU for calculations, and won't ever.
- Better content diversity and progression with mods, but struggles to maintain sync in certain areas when running the most popular mod (Frackin' Universe) on a dedicated server with resources to spare—again, engine limitations are the culprit.

The ugly:
- Will likely never see an engine update to bring it up to speed with modern or continously updated titles
- Troubleshooting bugs is a nightmare with mods because many vanilla bugs still remain, and telling them apart can be tedious or a dead end
- Really no reason to play it over Terraria apart from the space aesthetic since the maps it generates for planets aren't special in any way, just the same jumble of random dungeons and blocks vomited onto the appropriate biomes. In Terraria, you can walk left or right to do the same thing that Starbound requires you to fly a spaceship for.

In short, Starbound was a very ambitious idea that partially delivered on its promise. Unfortunately, after nearly a decade since its "full release," it's far behind the times. Titles like Minecraft and Terraria continue to refine and innovate on everything from performance to content, but Starbound was declared "finished" and left to collect dust.

The game is better with mods, no doubt. Frackin' Universe, among others, add a layer of much-needed depth and incremental progression. But running these mods on a game engine that can only command a single CPU core—and it only runs on the CPU, using the GPU for nothing but displaying pixels—is a recipe for frustration.

Starbound is a beloved game to many. Simply rifling through the many Discord servers dedicated to its most popular mods will tell you the lengths people are willing to go to breathe some new life into it. Yet, it's also a deeply and fundamentally flawed game... and it's doomed to stay that way.

Music - 
So much of the game is about spelunking and caving, and while the Surface biomes do fine with playing some really amazing soundtracks, the caves are eerie and dull. I feel like there was a chance for the game to set a jubilant and bouncy sort of tone, but it took itself a little too seriously in this regard.

Radiant Quests and NPC Dialogue - 
In a space game, the whole point is that you get to interact with aliens and stuff, especially in an RPG like this, and yet all you can do is press 'E' to probe NPCs for small talk and that's it. The quest system is also really too simple and unrewarding, especially with the abundant nature of almost all craftables and resources you can acquire invalidating the value of the rewards you receive. 

Main Questline - 
A lot of people have talked about this, but basically, the entire main storyline is a tutorial. I'm not even joking. You spend ~15 or so main missions all the way until you make it to the final boss before you realize you were supposed to be building colonies and bases, but instead you've just been living on your ship the entire time. Too much of this game focuses on the questline and not on the core sandbox nature of the game, and by the time you ever confront this aspect of the game, you're hardly ready for it. Either you try out the sandbox stuff right in the beginning before learning you haven't unlocked 80% of the tools you need or want, or you try out after completing the story, and it feels pointless without any other side goals to be working towards. The game really should have focused more on a town-building aspect in my opinion.


But yeah, you can probably tell I really did enjoy the aesthetic of this game, and I also found other things of interest like through modding and multiplayer. It pulls the game in two different directions that confuses the player, so to change this, they added a storyline that was primarily about boss-fighting and herodom: all well and good, but it didn't fix the primary issue. 

This game could still be so much more, but it's been so long since the developers have been around and even they did not seem to realize what this game needed. Mods are wonderful, and apparently some level of the community persists and continues its work on this game, but there's only so much you can do with the main game. 

I know I am being very critical, but I just wanted to push out some of my main issues with the game, that I haven't seen other reviewers mention.

Biased review:

I helm the largest mod for this game, and have more playtime than...well, anyone else on the planet that owns this game. Bear this in mind in my review. Firstly: Terraria players will both like and dislike aspects of Starbound. Going into this game as a Terraria player, do yourself a favor: Don't compare the two. Beyond the digging and building there are very few similarities in gameplay. 

Starbound is a sandbox exploration game, with emphasis on Exploration. You're meant to explore and see the universe, and in a way that is structured far differently from other titles in the "voxel" genre. It excels in giving the player fun places to visit and a variety of things to do in said locations. Building is exceptionally well handled and there is a very wide array of content suited to this sort of gameplay, including being able (for a modest fee) to 3d print things you have already encountered in order to build to your liking with less hassles.

Combat is passable, but not the core focus of the game. You *will* be fighting, and there are some rewarding and interesting dungeons and boss fights...but don't let that lure you into thinking the game is about fighting. Not the base vanilla product, at any rate.

Tiering is handled intuitively, with each new star type explored (again, in the vanilla product) opening up new ores that in turn lead to new armor, which takes you into the new tier of content. In fact, most "tiering" is loosely based on your gear. It's an interesting way to handle pacing, but at times may have you confused as there is little in-game to inform you of this. You are intended to find out on your own. If you like having your hand held like many games these days do, it will not happen here. Like Terraria, you need to figure out wtf the ores do on your own.

There are numerous sub-systems in play that add life to the universe (Mechs, Space Stations, with Bounty Hunting coming soon). Unfortunately, these sub-systems are probably the weakest link. The content for them is fine...but their integration doesn't connect directly to tiering in any logical way, and they play no overall purpose in the games narrative. You can completely ignore all of the mech content, and suffer nothing for it, for example. This gives the feeling of them being "tacked on" rather than implemented naturally. This is both a blessing and a curse. You aren't forced to use the content, but it makes it feel hollow and lacking.

There are all sorts of things to like, though: Atmosphere, a beautifully composed soundtrack that perfectly encapsulates the feel of the game, unrivaled building mechanics, fun gameplay and a variety of difficulties that give different sorts of players a very difference experience (Hardcore mode for those who love to punish themselves, Casual for those that are the opposite). The same sub-systems I mention above add a lot of fun despite their downsides, and when it comes to modding...

There are few games that allow you to modify this much with of product right out of the gates. Over the course of 5+ years my own mod has effectively rewritten most of the core game with few headaches along the way. Being able to rework almost (key word: almost) the entire product without access to the sourcecode is fantastic, and the devs are receptive to improvements to this modding capability.


In short:

Pros:

- Tons of content
- Billions upon billions of possible planets can generate
- Building in this game is *awesome*
- Intuitive and straightforward
- Numerous interesting minigames
- Randomly generated creatures
- Randomly Generated quests
- Soundtrack is amazing
- Atmospheric
- Nearly unrivaled modabilty
- Play the game however you want (see first point in cons for exception) 


Cons:

- While you can play how you want, you must first complete some intro quests no matter how many times you've played the game, and no option to skip those initial "learn to play" bits. This means there is one mandatory dungeon every single time you play. You *can* skip the Introduction, however. 
- Sub-systems feel tacked-on rather than integrated
- Meh UI
- Somewhat shallow without mods after a playthrough
- Mods are almost essential to tailor gameplay for your specific tastes


Despite the cons, this game is largely what you make of it. 12k hours should give me some street-cred there.

I have played Starbound since its Early Access days, and it is easily my favorite game in sandbox exploration/building genre.

Among the games of its genre, Starbound puts strongerest focus on exploration rather than fighting. Rather than adventuring in a single world, in Starbound you travel between different planets each not only belonging to a particular biome, but containing some of unique features from a fairly large list, from peaceful villages to dungeons filled with zealous guards. So you never know what you will find on each new planet you visit, which makes exploration very addictive: you will always want to explore “just one more planet”!

In regard of building, Starbound offers one of largest (if not the largest) selections of both decorative and functional items to place in your house or base. It also has mechanics that allows you to populate your base with as many NPC as you like, potentially building a whole town with dozens residents.

And uniquely among its genre, Starbound also has quests like one might expect of a RPG rather than a sandbox building game: a fairly long main quests and an infinite number of random quests provided by NPC in towns or those you've placed in your home or base yourself.

Only one aspect of Starbound is somewhat lacking: combat, or specifically, its difficulty. While you may encounter some difficulty if you are poorly equipped (especially at the very start), as long as you are equipped with a gear of the same tier as the planet you are exploring, you will likely have little difficulty fending off local wildlife. There is some difficulty during boss fights, but bosses are still easy as far as bosses go, and if you expect challenging battles that Terrarria or action games offer, you won't find them in Starbound. Some storyline and random dungeon can also offer some challenge, but there it mostly comes from traps or indestructable dungeon elements, like flamethrowers or laser beams, not enemies (in fact, random dungeons often have few to none enemies, and focus on making you avoid dangerous environment).

So, overall, the combat isn't that bad. Just don't expect constant challenge that Terraria or Edge of Space present.

I fully recommend Starbound to anyone who likes sandbox games or want to give this genre a try.

This game is one that is very, VERY difficult for me to put my finger on. It exceeds expectations in so many areas, yet still manages to come up short in many others. It's a very ambitious game, that's for sure, it always has been. I remember the early days of this game, when it showed so much promise. There was no storyline, no scanning missions, nothing like that. It was just you, your ship, and the universe. You would progress by mining materials and beating bosses to upgrade your gear. It was very much "Terraria in Space". But now it's somewhat different. It grew into something different and established its own identity, both for better and for worse. 

It offers a storyline that serves both as a narrative to give the player incentive to continue, as well as to streamline the process of progressing from system to system to help the player understand how the difficulty progression works. The narrative itself shows some promise at the beginning, but it ends up falling flat at the very end. As for the missions to guide the player through the story, well... It's just scanning items found in the cities of each of the races (aside from Novakid, for some reason). That's it. While I understand the reasoning behind this decision, it's just... not very fun at all. You're supposed to get that planet's "Tier Mineral" (Tungsten, Titanium, Solarium, Etc.) before taking on that tier's dungeon, which is why they have you do these missions, but I just feel like the scanning missions aren't any good. I feel like it would have been better if the mission was to just land on the planet, find a civilization and talk to an NPC, have another mission to gather a certain amount of that planet's "Tier Mineral", then allow the player to take on the next dungeon. At least, that's how I'd do it.

As for the exploration, it's utterly fantastic... at first. There's a sense of wonder and excitement jumping from planet to planet at the start, but it begins to wear off after you discover the same types of large structures over and over again on each planet. There's quite a bit of variety between the different types of planets, but when it comes to a single planet type, there really isn't too much to write home about, unless you're exploring underground, where you can find all sorts of weird structures and biomes.

When it comes to performance... yikes. It's got some major issues in the optimization department. It has some strange stuttering and freezing issues at seemingly random points, though thankfully in my experience they've been very infrequent. However, this does not negate them entirely. Multiplayer is a bit of a mess too, especially when it comes to hosting modded dedicated servers. Thankfully, the community has made tools that makes this much easier, but it doesn't fix the fact that the multiplayer connectivity is very shaky, even with the best setup.

Despite all of this... I still find myself wanting to play this game. Despite all my gripes above, despite me thinking that it has some really questionable design choices, and coming up short in several areas... I get a lot of enjoyment out of this game. The possibilities for construction are utterly astounding. There are so many block types and styles, you can build almost anything you can think of. The inventory system is pretty nice too. While it takes some getting used to, having things separated by item types allows for better organization, and makes the sheer number of items you can find a lot less intimidating. I think that above all else, though, the modding community is what makes this game exceptional. The sheer amount of variety and potential that is squeezed from this game with the mods is utterly astounding. People creating their own dungeons, races, storylines, planet types, progression systems, all sorts of things. It's absolutely insane how much the community has done with a concept like this. I have to recommend this product on that alone. It stands decently on its own merits, but once you dive into the modding scene, it becomes something truly special. 

Despite all of my criticisms, I do recommend this game to anyone looking for a space sandbox adventure. However, I think the best experience you'll get with this game is through playing with mods on a server with friends.

Since this game attracts the Terraria crowd, here's a review about what you should expect out of this game compared to Terraria. After all, Starbound is kind of like Terraria on steroids - it's bigger, and it actually has a quest component to it.

[h1]Starbound vs. Terraria: Gameplay Differences[/h1]

Even on the easiest setting, Starbound plays like Terraria Hardmode from the very beginning. There's a difference between 'hard' and 'obnoxious', though, and in my opinion, this game is in the 'hard' category. You'll have to get on your feet and learn how things work, but thankfully, this is easy to do as the game will guide you with a tip every time you discover a new item or action for the first time. 

If you've already played Terraria, you'll know how to jump right in to Starbound. The game mechanics are practically identical when it comes to mining, taking items, building houses and fighting enemies. It's bascially "another take on Terraria," as you'll see very quickly. 

Starbound has a bigger emphasis on food than Terraria. Food seemed nearly worthless after awhile in Terraria, but it is a necessity here -- especially on the harder tier, where you'll starve to death...this doesn't happen in the easiest mode, though. You'll start off finding and knowing about basic food, but different recipes will unlock as you discover other ingredients and make new items. Food not only increases health, but gives perks and stat boosts as well. Even on the easiest setting, food rots if you hold on to it for too long. 

[h1]Combat[/h1]

Combat is highly simplistic in Starbound, it is nothing more than hack & slash for the most part. Some monsters attack by nature, some don't, but the majority of them will simply chase you down and slam into you when attacked, making combat predictable and repetitive in this game. 

Unlike Terraria, you'll be able to access guns and other exotic items pretty quickly, unlike in Terraria where you have to complete a good portion of the game to unlock certain NPCs. For the most part - one handed swords swing quickly and allow you to use a shield in the other hand, but they are weak and will require many 'hits' to kill an enemy. Two-handed swords are slow, but do far more damage than a one-handed. Other weapons like axes and hammers require you to pull back the weapon with your mouse, and release to swing. Guns allow ranged attacks but are extremely weak and will require many shots to take an enemy down, but will allow you to do it from a safe distance. In the beginning, you'll want to stay far, far away from any enemy that has a gun - especially if it's a sniper rifle.

[h1]Look & Feel[/h1]

Starbound has the look and feel of an early 90s PC or SNES game, kind of like something made by Ocean or Sierra, as opposed to Terraria's more pixellated NES feel. Lots of quiet, soothing piano music. 

Starbound's "monsters" look like Pokemon rejects, which kind of gave the game its own characteristic. I prefer the huge range, style and diversity of Terraria's creatures more. Trees fall sideways when cut, and you'll be surprised when you see your first landslide when you're mining underground and hit a ceiling with loose rock or slime. This game has the same "biome" style regions as Terraria, where you'll venture from a forest to a jungle, or from a cavern to a slime pit, and eventually down to magma. Dig too far down and you'll fall prey to a long drop that leads directly to an infinite ocean of lava at the planet's core.

Starbound's building mechanics are more simplistic than Terraria's for the simple reason of hammers: they allowed you to hit blocks into "angles" and make tons of different and unique designs, corners and slopes in Terraria. No such thing exists in Starbound, where you can only place items in square blocks. There's no "corruption" or "crimson" style event that you'll have to worry about in Starbound, so, create what you want and don't worry about what will happen to it mid-way through the game.


For the most part, you take take or steal almost everything you see in Starbound, just like you can in Terraria, except on main missions (for example, your first real mission, The Outpost, where all of the chairs/beds/consoles/etc are locked down and immobile). For items that you can't craft, you may come across blueprints which are one-use items that instantly add the item to your list of craftables, one you have the necessary tool to do so.

When it comes to crafting, everything works pretty much the same between the two games. Craft a workbench-style item and it will allow you to create new items. In Starbound, you can upgrade these existing tool stations with specific materials to make better items. You'll find that in order to do this, better ore from outside your solar system is necessary.

[h1]What I Liked The Most About Starbound[/h1]

There are a few things that set Starbound apart from Terraria in my mind - the game's universe seems bigger and more "involved," because it simply is...you're no longer stranded on a single game world of small/medium/large that's created from the main menu, but an entire 'universe' is created for you when you first start a Starbound quest. You'll get your own spaceship, which can be decorated like a house, and will take you around the solar system without costing you any fuel. To see how big the game world is, zoom out of the solar system and take a look at the universe to see the other star systems and the planets in them. It's an exciting thing to figure out on your first play through.

I like the increase in difficulty that Starbound has vs. Terraria - it's easy to adjust to, and it makes you appreciate the simpler things more. Getting a better weapon is a gigantic milestone in this game, since they are far more difficult to find than in Terraria, and random chests don't usually mean uber weapons are in them...but, mediocre ones, or weapons that are only marginally better at one thing, but worse at another (damage vs. speed). You won't be crafting better weapons and armor for quite awhile - at least, until you get the courage to leave the solar system - so, you'll spend a lot of time mining and looking for abandoned outposts.

Being able to build structures to your liking and rent them out to alien tenants really takes the game to a new level.

[h1]What I Disliked The Most About Starbound[/h1]

The game has objectives and a questline for you to go through, which makes the game more interesting rather than Terraria's "grind and get more powerful", which becomes stale through time. While there are plenty of boilerplate "fetch" quests in Starbound, they'll force you to check out locations you haven't seen yet. 

Like all games with "procedural" quests and worlds, things get stale and unimpressive quickly. The random "mix and match" monsters in the game look ridiculous and have no real character. Random planets mix and match backdrops, trees and ground tiles which would seem to add diversity, but it kind of fails to do so.

The one thing that disappointed me are Starbound's "parallax" backdrops which look very infantile compared to the foreground objects - it's like having a children's cartoon backdrop in the background with foreground objects that are more serious and detailed, and it just doesn't "fit." Many of the biomes in this game are flat out horrible...such as, trees with eyeballs growing on them, and others with wacky neon colors and stripes that look like they came out of that Beetlejuice cartoon from the late 80s. I would have really preferred a consistent, serious look for the game. 

Overall, if you loved Terraria but got tired of it, you won't want to miss this one - it's a bigger 'take' on Terraria with a lot of bonuses that keep the game interesting. Mods take this game far above and beyond what it is, and you'll want to see what's out there in the Workshop.

While it's great that Starbound has by far some of the best mod support of any block-based sandbox game, I'm reviewing only what Chucklefish made here, and what they made... It's a frustrating mixed bag. I can see little moments of brilliance that hint at how this game could've been so much more, and yet, as it is, it feels like it's lacking quite a bit.

Starbound is a 2D Metroidvania-esque sandbox, taking a lot from Terraria--after all, Chucklefish was founded by and mostly consists of folks who previously worked on Terraria. You have a starship which is capable of travelling to any planet, asteroid field, or other notable celestial body in a solar system; you can travel to other star systems as well, but it costs Erchius Fuel to do so, which can be mined from moons (which happens to be an absolutely terrifying experience) or purchased at the Outpost, a hub of shops and quest-related stuff. The general gameplay loop is to mine for your current planet's top-shelf ore, craft a new tier of gear, craft a Protection Pack which lets you survive the next planet you have to go to, go to that planet, rinse and repeat.

So what makes this game feel so empty? The way I described this gameplay loop doesn't make it sound like a bad thing, right? Well... I think it has to do with the fact that you do this every single time with almost no variation. Terraria will shake things up constantly; you'll be mining only about 30% of the time, and the rest of that time is filled with god-knows-what. Starbound meanwhile gives you no real incentive to do anything but mine and get better gear; there are no unique NPC's with important items that you have to build houses for--only generic, randomly-generated ones. The main story does not at all help with this either, as it is almost as repetitive as this cycle of mining--scan items, teleport to dungeon (although the dungeons can admittedly be pretty neat), fight boss, repeat. This doesn't even begin to describe how uninspired the whole thing is as well, and its lack of cohesion; you mean to tell me this literal antithesis to a god that ate the Earth and the entire solar system for lunch can be easily defeated by some jackass with a glorified pickaxe and some machine pistols?

Some other gripes while I'm at it... The game runs [i]horribly[/i]. I was on a Ryzen 5 3600X with 32GB of RAM at the time of writing and this game can [i]barely[/i] push 60FPS in ideal conditions. I get a "gloriously" cinematic 20-30FPS on my densely populated ship, and on top of this the game tends to hiccup like GTA V. Honestly, this game might run worse than Yandere Simulator; at least that game has an excuse because it's in 3D. This is a goddamn 2D sprite-based game and it's running about the same or even worse. There are mods to fix it--when doing a new playthrough with friends, we installed a modpack that included performance optimizations, and thanks to that as well as an upgrade to a Ryzen 9 5900X, I was actually able to lock the game at 60FPS for the first time ever. [i]But you shouldn't ever [b]need[/b] a $550 USD workstation CPU, just to make a 2D sprite-based sandbox from 2016 run at 60FPS.[/i]

Another thing I hate are the crafting times; they weren't in the game back when it was in beta. You are [i]forced[/i] to just sit there with the crafting window open and wait for it to finish; if you close the window you cancel the crafting process. Wanna do a large-scale crafting project? Have fun waiting for each one of the 999 blocks to craft, dipshit. Some crafting stations also can take as long as 10 seconds to craft, which is just utter lunacy. It was so unbearable that I got a mod specifically to remove the crafting timers.

There are some absolutely brilliant things Starbound does though which make me wish the game was better, however. Unlike the janky nightmare that is Minecraft's Redstone or the tedious (although less so thanks to the Grand Design) process that is Terraria's wiring, Starbound's is dead simple--select wiring tool, select host, select target, connect the two directly with an invisible wire. That's it. [i]That's all.[/i] Additionally, it's almost always possible to return to your ship at any time with the press of a button--a far cry from Terraria requiring you to have a Magic Mirror or quit and restart to quickly return home, and especially from Minecraft, which basically just says "don't get lost in the first place then" or forces you to take a lava bath if you have keepInventory on. Placing walls is far more intuitive than Terraria too; left-click to place the building material as a block, right-click to place it as a wall. This is such an enormous improvement from Terraria where I keep getting stuck with odd numbers of walls left meaning I can't convert them all back into blocks. Another cool thing is how all your characters share the same universe, meaning that it's totally possible to have them all converge on a single planet; it makes you feel like the universe is more alive. All in all, these quality-of-life tidbits make Starbound [i]the[/i] example for other block-based sandboxes to follow when it comes to these aspects.

Starbound kinda feels like... If Bethesda made Terraria. Sure there's a lot to do on paper--in fact, there's an infinite amount of stuff to do on paper, thanks to repeatable quests. But all those quests are served to you by generic NPC's and are just one of the same few tasks repeated ad nauseam. The game feels unfocused, like it doesn't know what to do with itself, and it can't be motivated enough to really encourage you to do the myriad of things you actually can do in it.

And yet I still got almost 300 hours out of it. And that's because if there's one thing Starbound is good at, it's being a creativity tool for builders. The enormous variety of blocks and furniture combined with the simplicity and effectiveness of the building system allows for some incredible constructions--although you'll need to motivate yourself to do so, as your only real motivation the game provides are generic NPC's and a pitiful amount of rent. The combat also happens to be [i]just[/i] good enough to be a decent time; while the standard weapons are cookie-cutter with randomized stats a la Borderlands (except the manufacturer doesn't even matter), some of the unique weapons are very enjoyable to mess around with.

So... Do I recommend Starbound? Sure. It's far more flawed than Minecraft and Terraria, yes. But if you're okay with making your own fun, and you can get into a zen mindset for the more mindless parts of its gameplay, Starbound will be a reasonably fun experience for you.

By the way... I should mention that the folks at Chucklefish aren't exactly good people, by... Any stretch of the imagination. If you're not okay with buying games from companies that exploit others and have bad workplace cultures, you should probably stay away from this one.

Starbound is a side-scrolling exploration game with crafting, survival elements, varied environments and missions. It is a game that truly does live up to the "freeform gameplay" tag that a lot of these kind of games claim. The universe is a huge, randomly generated place full of varied planets, moons, anomalies and other friendly (or not so friendly) other ships. It is playable in single-player and also via drop-in-out multiplayer and dedicated servers.

Progression is a really well done mechanic in the game. There is no "XP" for tasks at all. You simply get better at doing the things you do by doing them - via better materials, tech and experience. This then allows you to take on greater challenges. The early game consists of "survival", where your ship is stranded, orbiting a planet. From here you must gather by mining, looting, exploring and dungeon crawling on the planet to make yourself better gear and establish a foothold. Once you have a base and a way of generating food you can then plan out your next big excursion. This area of the game gives you a good opportunity to explore the systems in place and mess around, without too much hassle. When you feel you are ready to experience the rest of the game you fix your ship and suddenly the game opens up into a much more massive and more complex being, which had me in awe. After that you are free to do whatever you want - you can go for the main quests or choose something else entirely. There is a main storyline, which centers around finding the [strike]infinity stones[/strike] artefacts of 5 different races. This can be tackled at your own pace. The game also offers side quests from planet inhabitants and also the many different species on the "Outpost" (an intergalactic shopping mall in space).

Your character can be equipped with a variety of different "tech", enhancing their abilities. How about the ability to wall-run, double-jump, dash or even turn into a sticky "ball" that can climb up walls and onto ceilings? Your character is further customised with an extensive armour and clothing system, which adds to certain abilities and allows you to enhance the aspect of your character that you want. Melee, ranged, duel-wielding guns, shotguns, rocket launchers, flame-throwers, magical staffs - you name it it has it. Find a play-style that works for you and go nuts with it. The variety here is great.

Fairly early on in the game you are also given a Mech - which can be deployed on planets or in space. The mech is particularly useful when mining for ship fuel on moons where there is no atmosphere or boarding other ships and stations to loot, trade or attack. This, like with everything in the game can be upgraded and customised to your liking. Quests also give you access to hiring crew members, which in turn upgrade your ship and give you companions to help you on your travels.

The crafting and building systems are actually quite detailed. You are given a "Matter Manipulator" at the start of the game, which can be upgraded as you play. This is the basic tool you use for terraforming. Later on it can also be used to collect liquids, paint and lay wires to connect objects that interact with each-other. Planets can be changed to your liking - you can create bases, houses, farms or anything else your imagination comes up with. You can even make a business out of it: for example, you can turn your farm into a food business and ship off the food you make for profit or even create housing for the local inhabitants of the planets and become landlord to receive rent. You can even make a zoo, with the intent on harvesting rare materials. There really is so much you can do here that it's mind-boggling to come to terms with the scope. Thankfully, the intuitive building system makes it quick and easy to make things. As you learn additional blueprints and mine more advanced materials you can craft better and better things. Not just buildings either, but armour, weapons, bombs, tools, furniture and technology.

So, in summary: the game is great. There is an enormous amount of content that will keep you playing for hundreds of hours. Thanks to the addictive and intuitive mechanics in play, it will also keep you coming back for more. Build, craft, loot, explore, hunt, dungeon crawl, run a business empire - it has it all.

The main quests often send you to find objects and settlements scattered among the stars and, unless you're playing on a server with previously explored worlds, everything is new. The races are all different and have various "themes" to them, and searching through villages to find specific furniture pieces for quests is one big scavenger hunt.  The worlds themselves have different biomes and mini biomes, with certain structures appearing only on certain worlds.  The backgrounds and music changes for various biomes, too! At times like this I wish there was an in between recommended and not recommended. I've spent 2,000 hours or so in this game, most of which coming from when it was first being developed, and at the time I had high hopes for it. There were a lot of promised features that were meant to be included as the game developed, and in time it became apparent that that just wasn't going to happen. It's been several years since the last update, and at the time of writing this I can safely say that Starbound isn't a bad game, but it definitely isn't that *good* of a game either.

----=== Pros ===----
[list]
[*]The playable races. Starbound has six playable races in vanilla. All of which have their own unique set of armors, themed building materials, and furnishings. Mods can add even more playable races.
[*]Procedural monsters are a fun way to make each planet feel like they have their own unique wildlife.
[*]Procedural weapons make exploration surprising. You never know when you'll find something much better than what you're using hidden away.
[*]Recruitable NPCs to take with you where ever is neat, some of the randomly generated designs they have can be really cute.
[*]The ability to redecorate your ship by tearing down the walls and replacing them with something more suitable for your aesthetic is great. The ship decorating is one of my favorite parts.
[*]Later game armors branching out into different sets to suit your playstyle is a nice. 
[*]The modding scene is huge. There are hundreds of addons that you can get to make your experience more exciting and more adventurous. It can make for many *many* hours of game play.
[*]Building is handled very well. Any block can be used as walling. Certain block combinations can look really wonderful when used together to make a building.
[/list]
----=== Cons ===----
[list]
[*]The game is abandoned. Starbound hasn't been updated in years, and to this day the game is horribly optimized, with bugs that will never be fixed. Multiplayer has been unstable since the beginning, even more so with mods installed. The frame rate being unfixed makes playing with friend who have more or less frames than you a bad time.
[*]Vanilla on it's own gets very stale rather quickly. There just aren't enough planet types to make exploring feel different. Starbound initially advertised a very large scale planetary adventure with atmospheres more alien in comparison to our own. In the latest build, most of the planets, aside from the alien and midnight worlds, simulate very earth like environments down to their colors. Most grass being green, most dirt being brown, the sky being blue. The universe just doesn't feel as alien as one might expect it to be.
[*]The game relies way too heavily on modding to be entertaining. Many of the systems in Vanilla don't feel polished or very finished. The crew mates you can recruit were a great idea in theory, but in practice their AI and path-finding just isn't up to code for them to be very useful for exploration or otherwise. The bounty hunting system gets really repetitive much too quickly.
[*]In the beginning, each race was meant to have their own story missions. Each of them starting with hints of something larger. The avian discovering the worship of Kluex being a conspiracy, to the floran tired of tribal life and wanting to learn, the human fleeing Earth during it's destruction. Each of the races had something deeply unique and interesting within the lore, most of which was much darker in earlier builds. For all of that to be replaced with standardized "save the universe" story just feels sad.
[*]Racial traits were a planned feature that never made into vanilla, unless you want to count the novakid gun crafting and glow in the dark. Each of the races were meant to have strengths and weaknesses that changed how they played.
[*]Most, if not of interesting planet generation is on the surface. There is no reason to go underground unless you need ores. On top of this, the structures on the surface of planets just aren't different enough from one another most of the time.
[*]The addition of *unique* creatures makes planets, again, feel too similar to one another. Unique creatures are much more common than procedural creatures making more alien fauna on planets even less common.
[*]Planet generation was never overhauled to fit the tighter platforming that came with launch, leaving many many steep hills that you're forced to dig through or build over. Vehicles are useless because of this as well.
[*]Tech before launch was much more varied, most being very different from one another. This would be replaced with standardized techs that behave much too similarly to each other.
[*]Only a small portion of the 60+ songs in the soundtrack is used in gameplay. Most planets sharing the same music with very few of the biome specific tracks being used.
[*]Speaking of music, If a song on the planet's day time track list is playing and that same song is on the night time track list it will endlessly play until you leave the planet. This is a bug that has existed since alpha that has never been fixed, and is extremely grating after a while. You should not need to drop what you're doing just because you want to hear different music.
[/list]
There is . . .  much much more that I probably should be mentioning here. However I'm going to be here all day if I include it all.

---=== Conclusion ===---
Starbound is a game that had potential. It can be fun to play with friends, assuming you all have similar frame rates. Mods are a great addition to the game, but they can't fix the bugs and optimization problems the game has. There was a lot that was promised when this game was being made, however only a handful of the features made it in with several new ones being added toward launch. A lot of said features not receiving polish or even being finished or being replaced with lesser, less iconic versions of what they were planned to be. In the end, Starbound is just an okay game.

On the surface, Starbound looks like a Terraria IN SPAAACE. While that may hold some merit in describing the game, it's survival features, sprawling universe, interesting creatures, and unique setting do make it stand out. This game is very dear to me; many classic memories of hijinks with my friends, back in Early Access. To this day, we call disappointment with a game due to too much playtime in Early Access "Starbound Effect". But perhaps that's for the best - even if you've only playing this now, this game still has it's fair share of problems.

Credit where it's due: the game's art style is lovely, the music is great, the concept is good and there are some pretty interesting ideas at work here. But here's the problem: it's just not very fun to play. 180 hours came mostly from Early Access play and then two earnest attempts to play it after launch. Never got particularly far.

I'll elaborate more, both on good and the bad. But mostly the bad.

[h1]The Original No Man's Sky[/h1]
When NMS was getting hyped into the outer orbit, I was watching with a raised eyebrow: it looked exactly like what Starbound was promising a few years back, except in 3D. So I wasn't too surprised when NMS didn't turn out too great, because again, Starbound also didn't.

I remember saying: "Starbound is the messiah of gaming, the game to end all games!" I mean, Terraria with space exploration and fantasy races? Infinite worlds to explore? Well... technically, that's all true. But Starbound suffers from the same general problem as NMS, and many other games besides.

[b]Procedural generation cannot create meaningful content.[/b]

Human brains are pattern-finding machines. We can easily tell when something's been jumbled together from pieces that you've seen before, with similar patterns. And because of that, all monsters feel the same; all terrain is the same hills, recoloured. There are bespoke, handcrafted elements - and those are very nice, amazing even. But it's all ruined when you end up finding the same Floran village again and again, the same Apex outpost, the same Glitch keep.

[h1]Progressing to Nowhere[/h1]
And you have to visit all those places, because in order to progress with the story, you have to visit places with settlements and scan objects belonging to different races/cultures. This sounds like a pretty solid idea for a plot, if it wasn't for the sameyness... but that's not the only problem.

The combat doesn't feel very meaningful. There are different kinds of weapons, stats, buffs and whatnot... but everything feels very haphazardly cobbled together without any idea of balance. Some pieces of gear are just so much better than others, and a lot of stuff you'll find is complete garbage. Enemies also feel either too easy or too hard. This is mostly because different planets simply offer different 'tiers', kind of like level zones, and you can tell which one it is based on the star colour and planet type.

Of course, in order to progress to harder planet types you need stuff to keep yourself alive, such as a better space suit. And in order to craft it you need specific materials, found in other, a bit less difficult places. You get the idea. It's actually a bit like in Terraria - to beat this boss you need at least this tier of gear. But here it just doesn't feel as good. Not sure why.

[h1]Bonfire with Friends[/h1]
So the game is not very good. But there are two things it's actually quite amazing at. One - building and customisation. There are so many different building blocks in this game, so many different objects to decorate your settlements. Different kinds of crops which you can use to cook different meals. Different outfits, hairstyles, even idle body poses. If building is what you like, then oh boy, does this game have building. It's all optional, too - you can become a space landlord, building colonies and getting rent money from your tenants. 

And two - hanging out with your friends. After you've built your base you can get together with your mates and play instruments, sit down, go for a nice walk, have a chat. It feels incredibly cozy, with the fantastic atmopshere and nice music. The instruments part is particularly memorable; even if it was rather annoying at the time, I'll always remember the goddamn robot playing the first 10 seconds of "Jingle Bells" on the accordion as me and another friend crossed the desert. Or the flower dude crying because our house is "not gay enough" (gay here meaning pretty/fancy) as it was still a work in progress. We made it gay enough later on, with a nice balcony, so he stopped crying. Or, or! Mining shirtless with the boys out of a barebones house because all our items fell into lava...

Those two things are probably why I have those 180 hours on record.

[h1]Conclusion[/h1]
Even after all these years, the game feels unfinished. But I think its main problem is that it doesn't focus on what it does best - handcrafted content. If this game's world was static and bespoke, it would've been a lot better, in my opinion at least. 

I hear a lot about mods, that they make the game better. Maybe they do, I haven't tried. I don't think that a game that needs mods to stop being bad can be called a good one. If you have some friends and you really liked Terraria, then it probably can't hurt to check this one out. But overall, the game simply fizzles out rather early on; it's illusion falls apart. At least the music is nice.

Starbound is a 2D survival-sandbox game that centers around driving around in a starship base and beaming from planet to planet to gather materials, advance the story, or build more permanent settlements. It has some very nifty takes on the genre, generating a galaxy with quadrillions of planets to visit, each with a host of biomes and aliens before No Man's Sky was a thing. Plus, you can play as a space furry, that's always a plus in my book.

Unfortunately, this game is slow, in a lot of senses. It's slow in the sense that the main story is padded out in a way that's unfriendly to the player, it's slow in that most of the secondary tasks and achievements are even more of a grind than the main story, and slow in the sense that it's poorly optimized. The optimization is probably the easiest to explain - the whole game runs on the CPU, and only on one core, and in addition to that there's a memory leak you can regularly encounter in gameplay that makes things grind to a halt.

I would recommend not going for the achievements if you choose to play this game, as well as getting a decent amount of mods to make things as efficient as they feel they should be. You can get mods to make crafting instant, or to remove the screen transitions that quickly add up as you beam from place to place with your ship's teleporter, or even skip the entire storyline that feels tacked on and adds little to the gameplay aside from a few really cool pre-made dungeons, but nothing can be done to fix the slowdowns caused by the poor optimization.

There's one more thing that people may want to consider before buying this game. Around 2019 word got out that a dozen voluntary contributors were exploited during Starbound's development, logging hundreds of hours with no compensation, many of them in their teenage years. A bunch of people who used to work with Chucklefish came out to confirm this happened, and it falls at the hands of company director Finn Brice, who also harassed nearly everyone else working there. I know it doesn't matter to everyone, but when looking at the worlds of this game, it pains me to think that people went through hell to get this game together and they weren't even given what they deserved in the end.

Starbound is, at heart, a lonely exploration game. There's lots of extra bits and bobs bolted onto it, but you shouldn't pick this game up unless you want to embrace the ambience of going to a strange alien world, exploring it and taking its resources, and then leaving to find another planet, knowing you won't be back.

Think No Man's Sky and you're right on the nose. No wonder this game has received such a divisive reception - Starbound looks like Terraria, talks like Terraria, and then it does something entirely different. Instead of creating a single world that's yours and shaping it into your fortress, your home, your...whatever - this is the lonely wandering experience of No Man's Sky, where you can build bases and get attached to places, but you always need to move on.

Unfortunately - and here's the biggest problem with the game - it has this beautiful premise, but it locks all of that exploration behind deeply painful content gating. My first few hours with this game were spent playing Terraria: I had to dig almost to the bottom of the starter planet, find some ore to unlock the main hub of the game, get told that if I wanted my ship fixed I had to fight a boss, and promptly discovered that because I hadn't spent hours crafting better gear I couldn't win.

So I nearly quit.

Instead I went mod-diving, hoping the community had fixed the game, and lo: they did. Frackin' Universe is the big overhaul mod that makes the game far more friendly, but there are other fixes as well: enabling teleporting anywhere, making chests hold more/be sortable by type, letting me add in custom races and more - the quality of life, the sheer amount of content in the game.... it fleshed it out.

Now I can't put Starbound down, because when I started over, I had better access to everything I needed to progress. I was also enticed by the promise of more things to craft, more things to do, more - everything! Mods didn't fix that initial grind with mining down to get those core fragments I needed to progress in the main quest, but they did make it far more fun and bearable, and once you're over that hump - the universe opens up to you.

Now I explore planets and visit alien villages and find maps to secret dungeons and I'm aiming to cook everything in the game, and I've built a teleporter that lets me come back to my own favorite planet, so I can work on building the base there. Now I'm looking for rare plants on exotic planets and upgrading my mecha and so much more.

It's No Man's Sky but 2D and stuffed with crazy amounts of content, with genuinely fun combat (shields are so much fun) and that lovely ambience of finding a little pond on an alien world and sitting next to it and watching the rain fall. Of finding a ruined prison still staffed with mad guards, and holing up in a cell and hoping they won't bust in before I can heal up. Of finding an Avian temple complete with lava pit at the bottom. Of - well. There's a lot here, and I won't be done for a long time.

Highly, highly recommended. But get yourself to the mods or else you'll wonder why you're bothering to play.

[i]This will be a bit different. Critical analysis of:[/i]
[h1]======================================[/h1]
[h1][b]Starbound[/b][/h1]
[h1]======================================[/h1]

[b]Note: Positive recommendation due in large part to development starting to come together well. I do not think you should buy this game at this moment, but you should watch.[/b]

[h1]TL;DR:[/h1]
Wait for release, and perhaps a little while after! See how the final stages of development goes! Make sure implementations of vital features and the way they intertwine are up to your par! Things have been improving, accelerating, and shaping up a lot lately...but you never know what one thing could ruin it all for you as an individual. As always, be wise with your money.

Do I at this point think release (or a few big updates after) will be worth your money? Yes. Do I think that it could also potentially be held back by a poorly implemented feature or two? Quite possibly. So if you have already purchased starbound...maybe it will soon be time to give it another go! But if you haven't...hold on to your wallets for just a little longer.

[h1]======================================[/h1]

[h1][b]In-depth Feature Critiques:[/b][/h1]

[h1][b]The Beginning:[/b][/h1]
You start out on a pretty planet, with a lush, colorful, friendly background. The terrain is usually mild in variation, making navigation fairly simple and quick. You are outright forced to dig down to the bottom of the planet--gathering ore along the way for gear--to acquire core fragments so you can fix your ship and go elsewhere.

Now, this may sound pretty annoying--and it is, however, many steps have been taken to make it a relatively quick and easy process. There are more caves and tunnels, making digging down to the bottom easier, as well as ore deposits that can be broken up to get a decent amount of a certain ore type. Underground sub-dungeons can potentially provide interesting loot, or just a needed change of scenery or some pixels.

[h1][b]The Planets and Exploration:[/b][/h1]
Upon gaining the ability to venture further, you may wonder just how good the new sights will be. The answer to this question: a mixed bag. Many planets seem boring and pointless, just a new color or different dungeon/settlement type. Maybe a cool biome or two...maybe a bunch of annoying biomes. Maybe there's no good loot. Maybe ore generation makes your desired type hard to find. To make matters worse, certain planet types tied to getting through the later tier are by nature incapable of being fun and unique. Ocean planets, for example. Mostly water atm.

On the other hand, it is very possible to stumble upon a planet with cool terrain, a cool settlement or dungeon with good loot, awesome looking background parallax and kickass trees, and an abundance of ore. Regardless, there needs to be more unique elements and reward/incentive to exploration. Things to make individual planets stand out and be special. Rare biome or dungeon variations, a strangely safe and beautiful planet of a dangerous harsh biome type, a different day/night cycle time, dangerous creatures and minibosses.

[h1][b]The Combat and Creatures:[/b][/h1]
Combat in starbound is fairly well setup. Weapons have unique properties and styles that generally enable you to fight however you want. Monsters now have better tells and more sensible windups, so blocking, dodging, parrying, and tanking are now all viable options. Since monsters are mostly generated off screen, and generally stay there, the end result is that combat often feels like a chore you do to get that one creature with that one annoying attack to stop impeding your horizontal progress around a planet.

[i]There is much room for improvement in that regard:[/i]

Loot should be more rewarding, fun, or varied. Monsters should seek you out and display unique behaviors. Perhaps some herd up, or fight in small roaming packs, or try to avoid you. Even if nothing at all is done to make it more engaging and fun, rather than like a popup when trying to surf the net, the spawning needs to be tweaked. I would like to see hardcaps on the amount of creatures that can spawn within a set distance of each other, or while you are busy killing other mobs, or how quickly it will populate the area past your sight with new monsters when you've just slaughtered five so you can finally resume moving forward.

[h1][b]The Functional Mechanics and Building:[/b][/h1]
They actually nailed this one. The matter manipulator is not only a lore-friendly tool, but an essential one. Digging and placing blocks can be precise, with ugprades to speed and tiles covered, the size of which can be adjusted on the fly. As a protip: You can even use it to help search for buried ore in the dark!

The building materials chosen for this process directly effect what you will get. This gives more purpose to the various biomes, and the exploration of them, because there are tenant NPCs that are based specifically on certain biome types. This was also very well done. Unfortunately, the availability of unique and varied building blocks in terms of aesthetics is limited. Aside from stone, many can only be scavenged from settlements or dungeons, no less! There are plenty of blocks that will end up having 100 recolors, as well, due to the nature of their planet, like sand and dirt. So why is there not a similar change in color and style not found in wallpapers on settlements, the color of bricks used in temples, and so on? Maybe one day.

The utility of the sci-fi exploration sandbox genre typing doesn't end there. A ship AI personal to your race is a clever way to dispense introductions to the game and quests, tips, and inform you if you try to do something like pay for an upgrade with too few materials.
